messageBody:
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi Phillip,


Am Donnerstag, 10. April 2003 17:26 schrieb
philipborlin@...:
> I just thought I would point out that (at least according to some) you are
> smoking crack!
>
> According to the Sybex book "The Complete Java 2" Second Edition (Robert,
> Heller, Ernest, pgs 192-193):
Just burn your damned Java book and smoke it!

> "Just like any other member, a member inner class may be marked static.
Nonsense. Either it is a inner class or it is static and then it's not an
inner class.

> When applied to a variable, static means that the variable is associated
> with the class, rather than with any particular instance of the class.
> When applied to an inner class, the meaning is similar.
That is nonsense. A class nested in another class can be made static, but then
it's not an inner class.

> Specifically, a static inner class does not have any reference to an
enclosing instance."
That's completely nonsense. Static inner classes do not exist.

- From the Java Language Specification, 8.1.2
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#262890

"An inner class is a nested class that is not explicitly or implicitly
declared static."
And from some paragraphs below:
"Inner classes include local (§14.3), anonymous (§15.9.5) and non-static
member classes (§8.5)."

Another statement, §8.5.2:
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#246853
"The static keyword may modify the declaration of a member type C within the
body of a non-inner class T. Its effect is to declare that C is not an inner
class."


The Java language specification clearly says that
a) inner classes are bound to an instance (so they aren't static)
b) nested classes marked as static aren't inner classes.


So now, the only one smoking crack is the author of your stupid book!


Bye
